servers

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/First-server-cern-
computer-center.jpg/220px-First-server-cern-computer-
center.jpg)](/wiki/File:First-server-cern-computer-center.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:First-server-cern-computer-center.jpg "Enlarge")

First [WWW](/wiki/WWW "WWW") server located at [CERN](/wiki/CERN "CERN") with
its original sticker that says: "This machine is a server. DO NOT POWER IT
DOWN!!"

In [computing](/wiki/Computing "Computing"), a **server** is a [computer
program](/wiki/Computer_program "Computer program") or a
[device](/wiki/Computer "Computer") that provides functionality for other
programs or devices, called "[clients](/wiki/Client_\(computing\) "Client
\(computing\)")". This [architecture](/wiki/Systems_architecture "Systems
architecture") is called the [client–server
model](/wiki/Client%E2%80%93server_model "Client–server model"), and a single
overall computation is distributed across multiple processes or devices.
Servers can provide various functionalities, often called "services", such as
sharing data or [resources](/wiki/System_resource "System resource") among
multiple clients, or performing computation for a client. A single server can
serve multiple clients, and a single client can use multiple servers. A client
process may run on the same device or may connect over a network to a server
on a different device.[1] Typical servers are [database
servers](/wiki/Database_server "Database server"), [file
servers](/wiki/File_server "File server"), [mail servers](/wiki/Mail_server
"Mail server"), [print servers](/wiki/Print_server "Print server"), [web
servers](/wiki/Web_server "Web server"), [game servers](/wiki/Game_server
"Game server"), and [application servers](/wiki/Application_server
"Application server").[2]

Client–server systems are today most frequently implemented by (and often
identified with) the [request–response](/wiki/Request%E2%80%93response
"Request–response") model: a client sends a request to the server, which
performs some action and sends a response back to the client, typically with a
result or acknowledgement. Designating a computer as "server-class hardware"
implies that it is specialized for running servers on it. This often implies
that it is more powerful and reliable than standard [personal
computers](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer"), but alternatively,
large [computing clusters](/wiki/Computing_cluster "Computing cluster") may be
composed of many relatively simple, replaceable server components.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The use of the word _server_ in computing comes from [queueing
theory](/wiki/Queueing_theory "Queueing theory"),[3] where it dates to the mid
20th century, being notably used in Kendall (1953) (along with "service"), the
paper that introduced [Kendall's notation](/wiki/Kendall%27s_notation
"Kendall's notation"). In earlier papers, such as the Erlang (1909), more
concrete terms such as "[telephone] operators" are used.

In computing, "server" dates at least to [RFC
5](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5) (1969),[4] one of the earliest documents
describing [ARPANET](/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET") (the predecessor of
[Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet")), and is contrasted with "user",
distinguishing two types of [host](/wiki/Host_\(network\) "Host \(network\)"):
"server-host" and "user-host". The use of "serving" also dates to early
documents, such as [RFC 4](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4),[5] contrasting
"serving-host" with "using-host".

The [Jargon File](/wiki/Jargon_File "Jargon File") defines
"[server](http://www.catb.org/jargon/html/S/server.html)" in the common sense
of a process performing service for requests, usually remote, with the 1981
([1.1.0](http://www.catb.org/jargon/oldversions/jarg110.txt)) version reading:

> SERVER n. A kind of [DAEMON](/wiki/Daemon_\(computing\) "Daemon
> \(computing\)") which performs a service for the requester, which often runs
> on a computer other than the one on which the server runs.

##
Operation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Operation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Server-based-
network.svg/220px-Server-based-network.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Server-based-
network.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Server-based-network.svg "Enlarge")

A network based on the **[client–server
model](/wiki/Client%E2%80%93server_model "Client–server model")** where
multiple individual _clients_ request services and resources from centralized
servers

Strictly speaking, the term _server_ refers to a [computer
program](/wiki/Computer_program "Computer program") or
[process](/wiki/Process_\(computing\) "Process \(computing\)") (running
program). Through [metonymy](/wiki/Metonymy "Metonymy"), it refers to a device
used for (or a device dedicated to) running one or several server programs. On
a network, such a device is called a _[host](/wiki/Host_\(network\) "Host
\(network\)")_. In addition to _server_ , the words _serve_ and _service_ (as
noun and as verb) are frequently used, though _servicer_ and _servant_ are
not.[a] The word _service_ (noun) may refer to either the abstract form of
functionality, e.g. [Web service](/wiki/Web_service "Web service").
Alternatively, it may refer to a computer program that turns a computer into a
server, e.g. [Windows service](/wiki/Windows_service "Windows service").
Originally used as "servers serve users" (and "users use servers"), in the
sense of "obey", today one often says that "servers serve data", in the same
sense as "give". For instance, [web servers](/wiki/Web_server "Web server")
"serve [up] web pages to users" or "service their requests".

The server is part of the [client–server
model](/wiki/Client%E2%80%93server_model "Client–server model"); in this
model, a server serves data for [clients](/wiki/Client_\(computing\) "Client
\(computing\)"). The nature of communication between a client and server is
[request and response](/wiki/Request%E2%80%93response "Request–response").
This is in contrast with [peer-to-peer](/wiki/Peer-to-peer "Peer-to-peer")
model in which the relationship is on-demand reciprocation. In principle, any
computerized process that can be used or called by another process
(particularly remotely, particularly to share a resource) is a server, and the
calling process or processes is a client. Thus any general purpose computer
connected to a network can host servers. For example, if files on a device are
shared by some process, that process is a [file server](/wiki/File_server
"File server"). Similarly, [web server](/wiki/Web_server "Web server")
software can _run_ on any capable computer, and so a [laptop](/wiki/Laptop
"Laptop") or a personal computer can host a web server.

While request–response is the most common client–server design, there are
others, such as the [publish–subscribe
pattern](/wiki/Publish%E2%80%93subscribe_pattern "Publish–subscribe pattern").
In the publish–subscribe pattern, clients register with a pub–sub server,
subscribing to specified types of messages; this initial registration may be
done by request–response. Thereafter, the pub–sub server forwards matching
messages to the clients _without_ any further requests: the server
_[pushes](/wiki/Push_technology "Push technology")_ messages to the client,
rather than the client _[pulling](/wiki/Pull_technology "Pull technology")_
messages from the server as in request–response.[6]

When referring to hardware, the word _server_ typically designates computer
models specialized for their role. In general, a server performs its role
better than a generic [personal computer](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal
computer").

##
Purpose[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Purpose")]

Main category: [Servers (computing)](/wiki/Category:Servers_\(computing\)
"Category:Servers \(computing\)")

The purpose of a server is to share data as well as to share
[resources](/wiki/System_resource "System resource") and distribute work. A
server computer can serve its own computer programs as well; depending on the
scenario, this could be part of a _[quid pro quo](/wiki/Quid_pro_quo "Quid pro
quo")_ transaction, or simply a technical possibility. The following table
shows several scenarios in which a server is used.

Server type  | Purpose  | Clients   
---|---|---  
[Application server](/wiki/Application_server "Application server") | Hosts [web apps](/wiki/Web_app "Web app") (computer programs that run inside a [web browser](/wiki/Web_browser "Web browser")) allowing users in the network to run and use them, without having to install a copy on their own computers. Unlike what the name might imply, these servers need not be part of the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web"); any [local network](/wiki/Local_network "Local network") would do.  | Computers with a web browser   
[Catalog server](/wiki/Catalog_server "Catalog server") | Maintains an index or table of contents of information that can be found across a large distributed network, such as computers, users, files shared on file servers, and web apps. [Directory servers](/wiki/Directory_server "Directory server") and [name servers](/wiki/Name_server "Name server") are examples of catalog servers.  | Any computer program that needs to find something on the network, such a [Domain member](/wiki/Windows_domain "Windows domain") attempting to log in, an [email client](/wiki/Email_client "Email client") looking for an email address, or a user looking for a file   
[Communications server](/wiki/Communications_server "Communications server") | Maintains an environment needed for one communication endpoint (user or devices) to find other endpoints and communicate with them. It may or may not include a directory of communication endpoints and a presence detection service, depending on the openness and security parameters of the network  | Communication endpoints (users or devices)   
[Computing server](/wiki/Supercomputer "Supercomputer") | Shares vast amounts of computing resources, especially [CPU](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing unit") and [random-access memory](/wiki/Random-access_memory "Random-access memory"), over a network.  | Any computer program that needs more CPU power and RAM than a personal computer can probably afford. The client must be a networked computer; otherwise, there would be no client–server model.   
[Database server](/wiki/Database_server "Database server") | Maintains and shares any form of [database](/wiki/Database "Database") (organized collections of data with predefined properties that may be displayed in a table) over a network.  | [Spreadsheets](/wiki/Spreadsheet "Spreadsheet"), [accounting software](/wiki/Accounting_software "Accounting software"), [asset management software](/wiki/Digital_asset_management "Digital asset management") or virtually any computer program that consumes well-organized data, especially in large volumes   
[Fax server](/wiki/Fax_server "Fax server") | Shares one or more [fax machines](/wiki/Fax_machine "Fax machine") over a network, thus eliminating the hassle of physical access  | Any fax sender or recipient   
[File server](/wiki/File_server "File server") | Shares [files](/wiki/Computer_file "Computer file") and [folders](/wiki/Computer_folder "Computer folder"), storage space to hold files and folders, or both, over a network  | Networked computers are the intended clients, even though local programs can be clients   
[Game server](/wiki/Game_server "Game server") | Enables several computers or gaming devices to play [multiplayer games](/wiki/Multiplayer_game "Multiplayer game") | Personal computers or [gaming consoles](/wiki/Video_game_console "Video game console")  
[Mail server](/wiki/Mail_server "Mail server") | Makes [email](/wiki/Email "Email") communication possible in the same way that a [post office](/wiki/Post_office "Post office") makes [snail mail](/wiki/Snail_mail "Snail mail") communication possible  | Senders and recipients of email   
[Media server](/wiki/Media_server "Media server") | Shares [digital video](/wiki/Digital_video "Digital video") or [digital audio](/wiki/Digital_audio "Digital audio") over a network through [media streaming](/wiki/Streaming_media "Streaming media") (transmitting content in a way that portions received can be watched or listened to as they arrive, as opposed to downloading an entire file and then using it)  | User-attended personal computers equipped with a monitor and a speaker   
[Print server](/wiki/Print_server "Print server") | Shares one or more [printers](/wiki/Printer_\(computing\) "Printer \(computing\)") over a network, thus eliminating the hassle of physical access  | Computers in need of printing something   
[Sound server](/wiki/Sound_server "Sound server") | Enables computer programs to play and record sound, individually or cooperatively  | Computer programs of the same computer and network clients.   
[Proxy server](/wiki/Proxy_server "Proxy server") | Acts as an [intermediary](/wiki/Intermediary "Intermediary") between a client and a server, accepting incoming traffic from the client and sending it to the server. Reasons for doing so includes content control and filtering, improving traffic performance, preventing unauthorized network access or simply routing the traffic over a large and complex network.  | Any networked computer   
Virtual server  | Shares hardware and software resources with other virtual servers. It exists only as defined within specialized software called hypervisor. The hypervisor presents virtual hardware to the server as if it were real physical hardware[7]. Server virtualization allows for a more efficient infrastructure.  | Any networked computer   
[Web server](/wiki/Web_server "Web server") | Hosts [web pages](/wiki/Web_page "Web page"). A web server is what makes the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web") possible. Each [website](/wiki/Website "Website") has one or more web servers.  | Computers with a web browser   
  
Almost the entire structure of the [Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet") is
based upon a [client–server](/wiki/Client%E2%80%93server "Client–server")
model. High-level [root nameservers](/wiki/Root_nameserver "Root nameserver"),
[DNS](/wiki/Domain_Name_System "Domain Name System"), and routers direct the
traffic on the internet. There are millions of servers connected to the
Internet, running continuously throughout the world[8] and virtually every
action taken by an ordinary [Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet") user
requires one or more interactions with one or more server. There are
exceptions that do not use dedicated servers; for example [peer-to-peer file
sharing](/wiki/File_sharing "File sharing"), some implementations of
[telephony](/wiki/Telephony "Telephony") (e.g. pre-Microsoft
[Skype](/wiki/Skype "Skype")).

## Hardware
requirement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Hardware requirement")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Inside_and_Rear_of_Webserver.jpg/220px-
Inside_and_Rear_of_Webserver.jpg)](/wiki/File:Inside_and_Rear_of_Webserver.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Inside_and_Rear_of_Webserver.jpg "Enlarge")

A rack-mountable server with the top cover removed to reveal internal
components

[Hardware](/wiki/Computer_hardware "Computer hardware") requirement for
servers vary widely, depending on the server's purpose and its software.

Since servers are usually accessed over a network, many run unattended without
a [computer monitor](/wiki/Computer_monitor "Computer monitor") or input
device, audio hardware and [USB](/wiki/Universal_Serial_Bus "Universal Serial
Bus") interfaces. Many servers do not have a [graphical user
interface](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface") (GUI).
They are configured and managed remotely. Remote management can be conducted
via various methods including [Microsoft Management
Console](/wiki/Microsoft_Management_Console "Microsoft Management Console")
(MMC), [PowerShell](/wiki/PowerShell "PowerShell"), [SSH](/wiki/Secure_Shell
"Secure Shell") and [browser-based](/wiki/Web_browser "Web browser") [out-of-
band management](/wiki/Out-of-band_management "Out-of-band management")
systems such as Dell's [iDRAC](/wiki/Dell_DRAC "Dell DRAC") or HP's
[iLo](/wiki/HP_Integrated_Lights-Out "HP Integrated Lights-Out").

### Large
servers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Large servers")]

Large traditional single servers would need to be run for long periods without
interruption. [Availability](/wiki/Availability "Availability") would have to
be very high, making hardware reliability and durability extremely important.
[Mission-critical](/wiki/Mission-critical "Mission-critical") enterprise
servers would be very [fault tolerant](/wiki/Fault_tolerance "Fault
tolerance") and use specialized hardware with low [failure
rates](/wiki/Failure_rate "Failure rate") in order to maximize
[uptime](/wiki/Uptime "Uptime"). [Uninterruptible power
supplies](/wiki/Uninterruptible_power_supply "Uninterruptible power supply")
might be incorporated to insure against power failure. Servers typically
include hardware [redundancy](/wiki/Redundancy_\(engineering\) "Redundancy
\(engineering\)") such as dual [power supplies](/wiki/Power_supply "Power
supply"), [RAID](/wiki/RAID "RAID") [disk](/wiki/Hard_disk "Hard disk")
systems, and [ECC memory](/wiki/ECC_memory "ECC memory"),[9] along with
extensive [pre-boot](/wiki/Preboot_Execution_Environment "Preboot Execution
Environment") memory testing and verification. Critical components might be
[hot swappable](/wiki/Hot_swappable "Hot swappable"), allowing technicians to
replace them on the running server without shutting it down, and to guard
against overheating, servers might have more powerful fans or use [water
cooling](/wiki/Water_cooling "Water cooling"). They will often be able to be
configured, powered up and down or rebooted remotely, using [out-of-band
management](/wiki/Out-of-band_management "Out-of-band management"), typically
based on [IPMI](/wiki/Intelligent_Platform_Management_Interface "Intelligent
Platform Management Interface"). Server casings are usually [flat and
wide](/wiki/Rack_unit "Rack unit"), and designed to be [rack-
mounted](/wiki/Server_rack "Server rack").

These types of servers are often housed in dedicated [data
centers](/wiki/Data_centers "Data centers"). These will normally have very
stable power and Internet and increased security. Noise is also less of a
concern, but power consumption and heat output can be a serious issue. Server
rooms are equipped with air conditioning devices.

###
Clusters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Clusters")]

Main article: [Server farm](/wiki/Server_farm "Server farm")

A _server farm_ or _server cluster_ is a collection of computer servers
maintained by an organization to supply server functionality far beyond the
capability of a single device. Modern [data centers](/wiki/Data_center "Data
center") are now often built of very large clusters of much simpler
servers,[10] and there is a collaborative effort, [Open Compute
Project](/wiki/Open_Compute_Project "Open Compute Project") around this
concept.

###
Appliances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Appliances")]

A class of small specialist servers called [network
appliances](/wiki/Network_appliance "Network appliance") are generally at the
low end of the scale, often being smaller than common desktop computers.

## Operating
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Operating systems")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Cobalt_Qube_3_Front.jpg/220px-
Cobalt_Qube_3_Front.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cobalt_Qube_3_Front.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cobalt_Qube_3_Front.jpg "Enlarge")

Sun's [Cobalt Qube](/wiki/Cobalt_Qube "Cobalt Qube") 3; a computer [server
appliance](/wiki/Server_appliance "Server appliance") (2002); running Cobalt
Linux (a customized version of Red Hat Linux, using the 2.2 Linux kernel),
complete with the Apache web server.

On the Internet the dominant operating systems among servers are UNIX-like
[open source](/wiki/Open_source "Open source")
[distributions](/wiki/Software_distribution "Software distribution"), such as
those based on [Linux](/wiki/Linux "Linux") and [FreeBSD](/wiki/FreeBSD
"FreeBSD"),[11] with [Windows Server](/wiki/Windows_Server "Windows Server")
also having a very significant share. Proprietary operating systems such as
[z/OS](/wiki/Z/OS "Z/OS") and [macOS Server](/wiki/MacOS_Server "MacOS
Server") are also deployed, but in much smaller numbers.

Specialist server-oriented operating systems have traditionally had features
such as:

  * [GUI](/wiki/GUI "GUI") not available or optional
  * Ability to [reconfigure](/wiki/Reconfigurable_computing "Reconfigurable computing") and update both hardware and software to some extent without restart
  * Advanced [backup](/wiki/Backup "Backup") facilities to permit regular and frequent online backups of critical [data](/wiki/Data "Data"),
  * [Transparent](/wiki/Network_transparency "Network transparency") data transfer between different [volumes](/wiki/Volume_\(computing\) "Volume \(computing\)") or devices
  * Flexible and advanced networking capabilities
  * Automation capabilities such as [daemons](/wiki/Daemon_\(computer_software\) "Daemon \(computer software\)") in UNIX and [services](/wiki/Windows_service "Windows service") in Windows
  * Tight system security, with advanced user, resource, data, and memory protection.
  * Advanced detection and alerting on conditions such as overheating, processor and disk failure.[12]

In practice, today many desktop and server operating systems share similar
[code bases](/wiki/Code_base "Code base"), differing mostly in configuration.

## Energy
consumption[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Server_\(computing\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Energy consumption")]

In 2010, data centers (servers, cooling, and other electrical infrastructure)
were responsible for 1.1-1.5% of electrical energy consumption worldwide and
1.7-2.2% in the United States.[13] One estimate is that total energy
consumption for information and communications technology saves more than 5
times its [carbon footprint](/wiki/Carbon_footprint "Carbon footprint")[14] in
the rest of the economy by enabling efficiency.
